arch:property.oc:show_val: Burial. Up to nine skulls, or sizable fragments found at the bottom of a pit or depression. Few long bones (in relation to skulls) were found. Human bones were mixed with animal bones. Bones were underlying and suspended in the dark and ashy L1715 and L1719 but few bones showed evidence or burning - secondary burials? Cremations? Bones showed no real order. Ie resembled a dump ( though the long bones were generally concentrated in the northern slope of the pit). Some of the skulls and bones also underlay mud-brick tumble L1718

Death pit - internal slope and contents (western half, eastern half was excavated by last year). The death pit slope belonging to L1938 is similar to the slope of the eastern half. However, underneath the slope of L1939 is much more shallow - perhaps this should have been given a separate feature number? These bones appear to be clusters of associated (?) bones arragned on flat soil with no slope evident. The slope of the death became evident before actual human bones were found (with the exception of F709). The outer extent of this slope is not known because there was not enough time to excavate it. The inner slope and edge of death pit was concentration of this year, mainly because of the amount of bones and the care required to excavate them! NB this feature was probed into L1939 with a small section of the trench at the end of the season in order to get the trench in shape for backfilling. Although this was given the same feature number as last years eastern exposure of the death pit although the charactersitics of this feature were different in this western exposure.
